text:
Praticamente un dolcione, un succo di frutta, troppo zuccherino. Non invitante al naso. Abbastanza gradevole, ma niente di che.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: MAY 3, 2017 Bottle at home. Slightly cloudy golden, slim but stable offwhite head. Candied light funky lambiek notes, lightly acidic, sweet peach and malty. Medium body and carbonation. Balanced in terms of the style, but too sweet for my taste.

Bottle, 375 ml, from Gem Shop, Zagreb. Shared with JFK10000. Pours orange, small, white head. Fruity, apples, some brown sugar, sweet, light sourish. Medium bodied. Not bad, but still bit too sugary for my taste.

0.375l bottle. Light amber color with quickly disappearing white head. Aroma is fruity with apples, sugary and little bit funky. Taste is sweet with some sourness in the finish along the sweetness. Overall its interesting beer.

Bottiglia. Il gusto al naso va verso il floreale. Lintensità olfattiva è elevata e la persistenza olfattiva è sufficiente. Il cappello di schiuma ha una scarsa tenuta e si fa ricordare per il pizzo finale. Le bollicine sono fini e la carbonazione è bassa. La consistenza del liquido è limpida. Anche qui le bollicine sono fini, con carbonazione media e persistente. Il colore è giallo ambrato. Il corpo è pieno. Il dolce è medio in equilibrio con lamaro medio. Lintensità gustativa è elevata e la persistenza gustativa è buona. Il gusto è piacevolissimo. Le sensazioni boccali finali sono di pronta beva. Il finale è felpato, pulito e dissetante. Il retrogusto è di media intensità. Al palato arrivano impressioni di miele, cereali, erbe e fiori

March 2017 - Keg at Le Trappiste, Bruges as Timmermans Faro, 4%. Amber orange, translucent, still, foamy off-white head leaves dotted lacing. Aroma is sugar syrup, pineapple chunks in syrup, slightly metallic. Body is smooth with tingly carbonation. Taste is again syrupy, thin apple liqueur, short finish. A very simple, sugary beer but one that didnt jar too much. Maybe one of the rare examples of keg cold-fizz helping a beer. Wouldnt approach a bottle of this one for that reason. (3.2)
Bottle at La cervesera artesana. Copper colour with white head. Fruity and apple aroma. Sweetm fruity, sugar, apple and caramel taste. Medium body.
375ml bottle. Pours dark orange brown with a medium head. Aroma is light sour funk and candy sugar. Taste has candy sugars to start and a sweet and sour barnyard finish. Some apple on the finish.

37.5cl corked bottle. Pours clear deep golden colour with a small white head. Aroma of mild sourish fruits, wood, stone fruits, sweet fruits. Taste of sweet stone fruits, apricot, some pineapple, a bit fry fruits, okay!

Bottle - Light sweet apple and white grape. Clear gold with a decent white head. Apple juice, no acidity and some light tea leaf. There is a touch of acidic bite on the throat, but no real complexity or funk.
Estilo Faro con zumo de manzana, de sabor igual a sidra champanada, muy suave con bastante cuerpo.

Bottle shared at THT. Clear golden with a small ring head. Aroma of light funk, caramel, citrus and tart light fruits. Flavour is above moderate sweet and light sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Bottle at February THT. Almost clear golden with very small white head. Sugary up front, sweet malts, light funk, hay, honey, a bit of puke. Quite sweet and very light sour. Medium bodied with soft carbonation.

Sampled from bottle at THT Februari at "De Zuipschuit". Clear gold with thin white head. Sweet rice pudding, sweet/sour candy, light gluey and cardboardy. Sweetness and sourness clashing, sweet wins. Medium body and low carbonation. Quite ok.
Un faro caramélisé agréable mais sans complexité, qui manque de fraîcheur et de notes de Lambic.

Gul, disig. Fruktig doft, syrliga äpplen och lite aprikos. Söt smak, mycket fruktig med äpple, aprikos och en liten blommighet. Bra fruktighet men lite för söt för att vara bra.
Provning på De Klomp
37,5cl bottle. Hazy dark gold, orange, light brown. Thin white head. Medium high sweetness. Medium thin body. Medium carbonation. Aroma is caramel, banana, spices, barnyard.
Fľaa Monk Brusel. Tmavá zlatá farba, bez peny. Vôňa sladká, jablková. Chuť sladká, jablká, jemne kyselkavosť. Dochuť sladká, opäť samé jablká. Prázdnejie telo, stredná nasýtenosť.
Clear amber body, no head. Aroma is apple, slightly sour. Taste is sweet with some sourness in the finish, apples. Thin body, soft carbonation.

37.5cl bottle. Clear copper with a thin white head. Sweet apple, light caramel and barnyard in the aroma. Average carbonation and light to medium body. Taste is sweet and sour with light citric and apple notes. Overall, nice but not remarkable.
At the MBR Sour Beer tasting. Thanks to whoever brought it! Dark amber body. Sugary aroma, figs. Extremely sugary taste, dust, figs. Eh. Way, waaay too sweet.

0.375 l bottle from Carrefour (Gent) as Timmermans Tradition Faro Lambicus, best before September 2018. Clear, golden amber with a medium large, frothy, rather quickly diminishing, white head. Sweetish-sourish, fruity aroma of lemon, gooseberry, rhubarb and slight hints of barnyard. Sweetish-sourish, fruity taste of lemon, gooseberry, some rhubarb, brown sugar and a touch of barnyard, followed by a short, slightly tart finish. Thin to medium body, smooth and a little effervescent mouthfeel, average carbonation. Not bad actually, not too sweet, some lambic is still recognisable and its definitely highly quaffable.
Bottle 0.375 l. Aroma: sour apple cider and champagne. Taste: light sour-sweet apple, dry finish.
Clear amber liquid no head. Aroma of straw. Taste is sweet and sour. Medium sweet, medium sour. Medium body, soft carb.
Bottle. Pours amber with minimum white head. Aroma: hay, farmhouse notes, raw apples, weak caramel. Taste: sweet, berries, sugary, apples. Nice. Maybe too sweet for me.

Aroma: hay, grass, 
Appearance: golden, clear, minimal head, white foam, 
Taste: heavy cloying sweetness, lightly bitter, medium sourness, 
Palate: medium body, sticky, average carbonation, long finish,

0,375l bottle at home. BB 09/06/2017. orange clear color, small white head. smells lightly sour / acidic, some fruits, belgian yeasty, some banana, doughy. decent smell. light body, soft carbonation, sticky mouthfeel. tastes quite sweet, honey, fruits, lightly citric, sweet apple notes, pears, a bit yeasty. finishes rather sweet with notes of honey and some fruits. overall okish, but much too sweet.

Danke an drnosha ,Bernstein schaum ok, Geruch schöner frischer geruch apfel leichte säure, unheimlich frischer antrunk säure sehr eigener Geschmack dann toll apfel wie frisch gerieben im Abgang der lang hält, ich finde es ein toller bier das absolut unter bewertet ist!

37,5cl Flasche mit Champagner Verschluss. Orange klare Farbe. Heller feiner Schaum. Saures Aroma. Apfel, Gurke mit einem Stich Essig. Kräftiger Apfelgeschmack. Gewürze, Tolles Süsse-Säure Verhältnis. Langer Apfelgeschmack im Abgang. Erinnert an einen sehr guten Cidre. Für mich ist dieses Bier völlig unterbewertet.

Clear amber color with a bit of light beige head. Aroma is malty with some Belgian sugar and a hint of balsamic vinegar. Taste starts sweet with a bit of caramel, malt and sugar. Medium body and carbonation. For a sweet lambic, its quite good. Not overly sweet and it also has a rustic feel to it.

F: big, white, good retention.
C: deep gold, almost clear.
A: malty, candy sugar, apples, caramel, light basement, some vegetal, hint of vinegar.
T: malty, sugary sweet together with tarty apple, peach fruitiness, citrus, mushrooms, light body, good carbonation, I am wondering by some high scores about this beer, for me refreshing but nothing special, lack of some complexity, 375ml bottle from Carrefour in Brussels.

Lambic dosladzany, slodki ale i przy tym na szczescie odrobine kwasny. Owocowy, wyczuwalne jabjka, Mala pianka, lekko metne, kolor jasnej herbaty. Zapach wyrazisty. Przydala by sie odrobina wiecej wytrawnosci

Bottle (from belgiuminabox). Pours amber with whiteish head. The small head stays for some moments. Aroma is mild funk, wheat, pears. Flavor is very sweet, some sourness, mild funk, fruits, bit watery. Overall: OK, feels bit like sweet lemonade with some lambic poured in.

(bottle) slightly opalescent golden-copper colour with a frothy off-white head. aroma of caramel, lemon juice and white bread crusts, with a hint of powdered sugar and some vanilla. flavour is mostly the same, lots of bread crusts and lemon juice, very sweet, with some notes of popcorn and grass in the rather empty finish. light- to medium-bodied with lively carbonation. surprisingly ok.

Piwo pomarańczowe. Piana średniopęcherzykowa, szybko redukuje się do zera, nie lepi szkła. W aromacie słodko, owocowo, lekki kwasek, W smaku słodko, słodkie wino, soczek jabłkowy. Spore ciało. Wysycenie średnie. Pijalne.

37.5 cl, bottled. BB 11/03/16. Pours clear dark amber with a minimal white head. Aroma: Toasted notes, honey, caramel. Taste: Sweet. Some mild acidity. Caramel, honey, toasted and floral notes, black tea. Palate: Medium body, quite dry. Notable carbonation. Not bad.
Bottled. Dark amber colour with frothy white head. Sweet nose. Aroma is sweet and a bit framboise and sour. Flavour mainly the same with truckload of sugar.

Bottle at home, 11/12/15.
Orange amber with a well appointed light beige covering that soon collapses.
Nose is light balsa, marzipan, Seville orange marmalade, ripe fruit, sweet candied sugars.
Taste comprises sweet sugars, candy bar, light must, mild tarteness to the fruit, quince paste.
Medium bodied, fine carbonation, caked with residual sugars in the close.
Way to sweet.
user_location: Hazlemere, the lower Xhitlerns, Buckinghamshire, ENGLAND

text: Alla spina. Dolciastra e leggermente acetica al naso, al palato è sproporzionata, troppo dolce, piacevolmente fruttata ma sembra contenere mezzo etto di zucchero di canna!! La vena acetica è troppo mascherata, ricorda quasi più una bibita.

Bottle. Clear orange color, small white head. Aroma is light barnyard and sweet wine. Taste is medium sweet, very light vinegar sourness. Flavor is sweet apple, candy sugar, sweet green grapes. Aftertaste is short with apple juice flavor. Not so bad.

[9/20/15] Bottle on a park bench in Brussels. Clear golden with a white head. Grainy lager aroma with a vegetal hint. Sweet flavor, candy-ish, sugary, grainy, with some fruitiness and a faint tart hint. Light-bodied, kinda sticky. Pretty bad.

Timmermans take on the commercial bottled faro style, bottle from Fontana in Sint-Niklaas. Loose, milky, light greyish white, irregular head, thinning out quickly and lying on top of a cristal clear, amberish orange beer with tiny dots of dead yeast floating around everywhere. Weird and all but inviting aroma of raw barbecue sausages (probably from proteins), cooked chicken, mouldy mushrooms, nutmeg, cigarette tobacco, green asparagus, dried orange peel, old apple cake, caramel candy. Sugary onset, marmelade and even a lightly lemonade-like sensation, soft (even almost flat) carbo, citrus peel accent but very artificial, smooth caramelly backbone, no recognizable lambic complexity, nor any bitterness of any significance; thin mouthfeel. The weird umami-like meat and mushroom aromas return retronasally and the sugar sticks a bit in the throat, but fortunately not in an exaggerated way; caramel malt sweetness lingers as well. Artificial citrus effect has more to do with ascorbic acid than anything else, I suspect. A true faro is unfortunately a rare phenomenon these days - whereas it was the most consumed beer style in 19th-century Brussels - but these bottled lemonade interpretations, initiated by Lindemans, were never a good idea and will not help beer afficionados from abroad to appreciate the style. If you want authentic faro, go to Cantillons museum and ask for one. Avoid this kind of artificial sugary crap. This bottle was too old in the first place and probably hasnt been kept in the best of circumstances, but I will not bother trying to find a fresh one, as it will have the same unpleasant sugary lemonade character and probably even more so than this old bottle. Unpleasant in more than one way - I hardly ever pour anything down the drain, but in this case, it did not take me a lot of time deciding its fate.  My expectations of this were low to begin with, but this is actually a lot worse than expected.

Bottle, 37,5cL. Home. A shining copper, light opaque, orange beer with a medium white head ; medium retention. Aroma of cider, light caramel, light woody. First, medium sweet, then light lasting sour. Light body, average texture, oily, high carbonation, sweet lasting finish. Overall, a pleasant faro, sourer than usual ; simple & nice.

Bottle from stirchley wines, shared with richthevillan. Golden amber beer with small head. Aroma is sweetish, light vinegarand funk. Taste is sugar candy, light funk and sweet. A little sugar on the palate. Very good.
user_location: West Bromwich (Yorkshire Expat), West Midlands, ENGLAND

text: Bottle shared with Sarkynorthener cheers Martin; clear amber pour with a thin off white head, aroma has sweet sugar some fruit, taste has a nicely balanced with sour, candied fruits, a hint of lemon.
375ml bottle. Hazy orange body with a low white head. Citrus, fudge, earth, tart and sugar. Too much sugar, unfortunately, as it completely takes over imo.
Strong toffee scent. great for refreshment. A good place to start if youre underaged.

A brown yellow colour, a head is almost medium and blond. Aroma is sweet, grapes and raisins, some apples. Taste has fruits, some raisins, strong sweetness, some sourness. Medium bodied, slightly sticky but also sparkling. Too sweet, otherwise OK.

375 ml bottle. Pours a hazy orange copper colour with a small head. Large visible bubbles. Aroma of sweet sugar, some cough medicin notes and also citrus. Flavour of chewy citrusy notes, cough medicin, sugary sweetness and sourness. Medium bodied. A bit harsh carbonation. Decent enough. Not overwhelmingly sweet nor sour.

Bottle pour. Pours a hazy, chunky gold with a white head of foam. The aroma is earthy and caramelly. Brown sugary. Not really all that appealing, unfortunately. Finished my bottle, but it was a struggle.

Pours clear golden. Not much froth.
Aroma is fresh fruit, such as cherry, strawberry, tangerine... Reminds of a Burgundy Pinot noir.
Taste is fizzy, sweetish, very sour yeast. Medium body, medium finish. Very lambic.

On tap at the Mariner Inn (aka Six North) in Stonehaven Scotland. 
Deep, dark amber body with a very good head. 
Very good feel: near medium body and medium carbonation. 
A little funk and tart in the nose 
Flavor: very different frm the aroma. Still some tart but much sweeter than tart. Lightly spicy with hints of cherries and other soft ripe fruits.

O: as per style, a touch too sweet for my taste but still much enjoyed.

Bottle @ home. Pours with a orange hazy colour, small diminishing white head. Aroma is quite fruity, but has also some more gueuzy notes, likes hints of leather; well balanced. Taste is medium to heavy sweet, medium sour, nice. Medium body, oily texture, soft carbonation. Great Faro.

10cl sample at the Zythos Beer Festival (Leuven, April 25th 2015). A two year-old lambic, which is absolutely top notch. Amber to orange colour. Mild sour, light sweetness, full taste through a well balanced palate. Very refreshing.

0.375 l bottle with champagne cork from local supermarket. Well, this is a sweet thing indeed, as it should. Faro is very refreshing in the next morning after too much drinking or too little sleeping. This traditional thing has still some hints of the sour lambic under the sweetness.
Bottle, cork and caged. Bronze pour with a small head. Apple juice, green pears, sugar, syrup. Refreshing.

37,5 cl bottle @ home, BBE 11.03.2016
Aroma has earthy notes typical to gueuze and sugary sweetness. Flavour has grapefruit, brown sugar, some earthy tones and citrus. Also some homemade mead vibes. Faro is still not my thing, the sweetness does not fit in.

March 11, 2015. Bottle at home, best before september 10, 2015. 
Clear reddish amber with a small frothy, quickly dissipating white head. Aroma is sweet with juicy apples, dark sugars, light funky and oaky notes. Taste is medium sweet apples with a light tart finish. Medium bodied, average carbonation. Positively surprised by this one, better than expected. Straightforward, maybe a bit simple, but good.
brewed by the worlds oldest lambic brewery; and what a great FARO it is. most pleasantly sweetened, traditional brew of great character. a great example of pure lambic style.
Bottle at home thanks to Kraddel, copper pour with sudsy head. Nose is apples and lots of sugar. Tastes of apples, musty, candied sugar, hint of sour. Very sweet not cloying though.
*Old rating, best before 10/07/04.  Süßliches Bier mit ein Bisschen Restsäure. Sehr süffig, nicht zu süß, stimmig, könnte aber noch ein bisschen mehr Säure vertragen. Nett.

Good fruity, sweet and floral fragrance. Well hopped fruity flavor. Perfectly balanced bitterness that fills the mouth forever. Gruesomely good beer. Follow me @ Kung av öl @ Facebook for more pictures and ratings.
375ml bottle. Delicious!! Sorry, my computer is dead. Tasting notes are coming soon!!
An okay lambic, more sweet than Id like, but the subtle funk is pleasant. Golden and crisp.
Fruktig och man känner på aromen att ölet är sött. Första smaken är mer syrlig av äpple men övergår snabbt till en sötare smak.
Een heel lekker biertje, goede geur, mooi kleurtje en een heel lekkere smaak zoals het hoort te zijn
Sweetened version of an already quite sweet lambic beer. I dont understand this need, especially for Timmermans beers.

Bottle from Bier Huis, Ossett. Clear, amber colour. Film of fine, white head. Aroma is baked apple. Brown sugar. Light, bready, yeasty tartness. Taste is soft toffee. Baked apple. Palate is fluffy soft. Light oiliness. Finish is light sweet, and light tart. A beer of contrasts. Nice beer.

Bottle at Delirium Cafe, pours a clear golden with a small white head. Aroma brings out candied sugar, light funk, and light wheat. Flavour is quite sugary sweet, with candied sugar, light caramel and maybe a hint of buried funk. Acceptable faro, but really sugary and simplistic. Not good.

37.5cl bottle served cool at home in a Hoegaarden Grand Cru tulip. Dark, crystal clear amber with an off-white head that recedes to a skim. Vinegary sweaty foot aroma, not unpleasant. Tart apple sweet and sourness in the flavour: You can taste the candy sugar, then a tart acidic sourness steps in. Medium bodied, astringent in the mouth, becoming slick as it provokes the saliva glands. Wouldnt want it as a session beer, but an interesting diversion on the beer journey.

Rousse, limpide. Odeurs de lambic ou de geuze fruité: en bouche par contre acidité très subtile. Effervescence mince, finale sucrée de cassonade qui arrive slm après la gorgée. Pas mauvais du tout, mais plutôt particulier point du vue style.
Light amber coloured beer with a quickly disappearing head. Light carbonation. Typical lambic sourness, but masked with a unnatural sweetness of added sugar. Not my cup of tea.

Bottle at home from Dicey Rileys
Light amber with fluffy white head collapsing to lacing. mildly tart, full bodied, slightly grainy, sweet.
Heerlijke Lambiek. Veel zoeter dan gebruikelijk. Licht zure ondertoon smaak met zoete toevoeging. Donker gele kleur. Smaak blijft niet lang hangen.

Bottle bier huis ossett. Dark amber colour shorlived head. Aroma is sweet and fruity. Taste is very sweet. Start followed by tart sourness mainly apple apple peel favours. Medium body low carbonation. I liked this the sweet and sour balance in the flavour works well easy to drink.

Bottle. Clear gold pour with generous white foam. Aroma of apple pie, spicy and fruity, something smells sour but not in a typical lambic manner, lemony/apple sour aroma, a bit strange. Taste is quite mellow, sweet but not overly so, very light sourness, like a nice fruit beer actually. Palate is light, medium carbonation. Not bad!
Bottle. Hazy golden color with a thin white head. Aroma of lemon, yeast, sour apple and apricot. Sweet taste of apple and apricot. Sweet finish.-- via beerbasher/winphone
Clear peach color with quickly dissapearing fluffy foam head. Aroma is little sour sweet. Taste is sugar dominated, some sour notes. Fresh sour aftertaste. (Velp 201310)

375 ml bottle in the Begijnhof. Lemony nose, light grass/dust, some caramel, sugar. Orange amber color, clear, with lace and light but persistent bubbles. Sweet and tangy, lemon, some light lambic funk and leather but not much, a bit lactic. Certainly not all that serious, but pretty tasty and quite drinkable. Good lemon flavors.
On tap. Aroma of apples and fruit. Amber colour with beige head. Rateher sweet with a ciderlike flavour and just a hint og yeast.
375ml bottle. Clear golden color. Small white head, disappears quickly. Jam, apples, sour, bit sweet notes in aroma. Weak aroma overall. Acidic, apples, sugary, bit metallic flavor.
Poured a cloudy amber with a frothy white head. Aroma of sweet, zesty candy. Medium. lively body, flavour of very sweet caramel with citrus and some spice.

bottle at kulmi . 
pours very clear blonde, small white foam. smells  aged though its only 3 years old.. 
taste is apples, sweet, sugary, no sourness left at all . it tastes too old already, but is still fairly enjoyable .

Bottle shared at Delirium. It pours clear amber with a medium white head. The nose is caramel, musty, mouldy wood and wet leaf. The taste is ice tea, apple, sweet pear and light tanginess with a sweet finish. Light-medium body, fine carbonation and slightly sticky mouth-feel. Yup far too sweet...

375ml bottle. Clear dark golden to amber colour with small to average, macropore, diminishing, minimally lacing, white head. Sourish and sweetish fruity aroma has notes of raspberry, plum and the like. Taste is sweet fruity, notes of strawberry, raspberry, plum, weak sourish counterpart; average to soft carbonation. Very sweet though still drinkable, surprisingly fruity.

Bottle @ Delirium, Brussels. Shared with Scopey. The pours deep amber with a small head The nose is sugary brown bread, caramel candy. Fairly faint aromas. The taste crazily sweet. Just very aggressive boiled sweets. Caramel syrup. Little else. Just aggressive sugary flavors. Light body, syrupy. Overall, pretty poor. Damn you, Timmermans!

Clear golden colour, dissipating white head. Aroma of citrus, apple, quite sweet, some caramel. Sweet flavour, apple juice, light sour touch. Light citrus in the finish, lots of sweet apple juice.
Apple juice is listed as an ingredient also in this beer, same as in the Tradition Gueuze, but here it seems to work out somewhat, and Im far less offended by it in a beer that is already supposed to be sweetened.
(From 33(?)cL bottle @ home)

Pours a cloudy orange with a small white head.  Sour wild yeast aroma.  Sour tart sweet caramel malt taste with an off but pleasant citrus and wild yeast mustiness.  I like this.  Its odd, but well balanced and enjoyable.
37,5cl bottle, BBE 20/06/14. Dark golden in color, frothy white head. Aroma has green apples, weak barnyardy notes and sweetness. Flavor has apple sauce, cand ysugar, light funkyness. Decent faro.

Bottle 37,5 cl, BBE 20.4.2014. Pours bronze in color with a whitish head. Light funk and notes of wheat in aroma. Sweet wheat and sour elements in taste at first. Aftertaste has that pleasant burnt grains feelimg with some sour notes as well. Fortunately this isnt that much sweet, which makes it quite enjoyable. Earthy, slightly burnt and sweet finish. One of the better lambic-faro Ive got to try so far.

Glass from a 375ml bottle, gracefully provided by tom10101, thanks a lot, mate! A light golden with a short-lived white head. Aroma is sweet and apples. Flavor is very sweet at first, with loads of green apples all over the finish. Quite tart, yet well-balanced. Easy drinking, very enjoyable.

Bottle (375 ml) at Café du Temps Perdu (Québec). Hazy golden with a small white head. Aroma is of sweetness along with subtle acidic notes. Taste is moderately sweet with a slight acidic/sour presence. Some fruits too. Light to medium body. Extremely drinkable. Sweetness isnt cloying. Solid Faro!

Bottle. Light copper, clear. Sugar cane on nose, some syrup, molasses. Quite malty also; almost lagerish- aromas. Body is lightish, taste leaning heavily towards sugar canes / unprocessed sugar. A touch of red apples, cinnamon. Some cola. Quite ok, but perhaps a bit too much of the sugary flavours. Theres a tad of acidity, and the body is quite light overall, but still..
Tap at Maxs in Baltimore.  Cloudy yellow with a white head.  Aroma is malty, sweet, a bit of sourness.  Flavor is a bit sweet, slightly grainy, sort of raw tasting?  A bit of a miss.

4oz pour at Maxs Belgian Fest.  Pours a clear orange with zero head.  Aroma is OK, grain, sugar, apples.  Flavor is cloyingly sweet, apples juice concentrate, stale malt.  Cloyingly sweet finish.  Not good.

Tap at Maxs Taphouse.  Pours clear amber with a small, frothy white head, short retention with light lacing.  Aroma is sugary cherry and raspberry with light cookie malt.  Flavor is malt forward with sugary fruity esters and a dry finish.  Light body and carbonation.

Draft, Maxs Belgianfest.  Crystal clear apple juice body with small white head.  Aroma is moderately sweet, orange/berry, some lemon.  Taste is sweet, orange, lemon, sugar -- nears oversweetened lemonade.  Light-medium body, some stickiness.
Bottle from a store in Belgium. Sweet and fruity smell, with ripe apples. Full body with lots of fruits, primarily ripe apples, actually tastes a bit like a apple juice. Very sweet. Quite refreshing.
Kind of amber colored. Smell and taste not good but the aftertaste is the worst. Musty and sourness came. Im NOT drinking this beer again.
Bottle thanks to Rasmus40. Slightly hazy amber with small off-white head. Aroma is malt, syrup, little tart and a little barnyard. Flavour is malt, sweet, sugar, syrup, little tart and candy sugar.

Bottle. Pours clear light golden color with decent white head. Aroma is apples, orange peel, basement aromas, sparkling wine and perhaps a hint of chilli peppers. Flavor is nicely balanced between sweet and sour, mainly apples, basement aromas. Aroma and flavor are perhaps not as strong as other lambics, but Ive otherwise quite enjoyed it.

Clear orange pour with a white head. Slight butter on the nose along with a pronounced sugar sweetness. Lots of apple, mild lactic tartness, and a hint of grass. Tastes like extra sweet apple sauce. Sugar, apple cider, and some celery. A touch of grass, mild acidity, and some light lemon notes.
Burnt sugar aroma (duh), some fruit. Fruity flavour dominates over the lambic and the sugar.

Sampled at an ESBLS tasting.  Light brown with a small and short lasting white foam.  The nose is sweet with brown sugar and light fruit.  Wow is this sweet and syrupy.  Some gentle spice.  There is a light bitterness with over ripe fruit.  Those barely compete with the sugar.  This is too sweet.

Bottle: Deep golden, visible carbonation, small and stable white creamy head, aroma of apples, malic acid with traces of toasted malt; moderate sweet-sour flavour,a bit more on the sweet side; mild sweet-sour finish, combined with a slight tartness. Nice thirst-quencher...
Bottle @ a random restaurant in Bruxelles for lunch. Clear golden with a white head. Aroma is sweet, malty, apples and candy sugar. Flavor is very sweet and light acidic. Quite sweet finish. 190712

Bottle @ Uncle Chris house in Fürth. Picked up in Brugge, I believe. A bit hazy, dark golden orange appearance with a cream colored head that doesnt last very long. Rich candy sugar, dark fruity, plum, dark grape, mild yeasty, zesty aroma. Well carbonated. Quite sugary, plum, dark grape, mild fig, tangy grapefruit citrusy, light lemon, somewhat sour, quite sweet flavor. I kind of like the dark fruit elements but the sweetness is over the top.

Bottle 375ml.
Pours golden/blond, with almost no head. Aroma is of sweetness, acid, sourness. Taste is of sugar, sligth lambic caracter, fruits, sourness. Overall: Good, but very sugary indeed.

Bottle popped in our room at tKeizershof. 

Pours an orangeish yellow color with a small white head.

The aroma is like sweet lime-aide, with a bit of sweat, and a bit of lemon rind. 

The flavor is very lemony and very tart, its got some earthiness to it and some dark sugar,  its really nice tasting beer save the cloying sweetness otherwise its perfectly nice beer, I imagine that if they didnt sugar it down so much this would be as good as the Cantillon Faro.

Corked and caged green glass 37.5cl bottle pours deep gold with off white head. The aroma offers up modest sweetness moving into sweet fruity tartness and a thin layer of mustiness. The taste is similar with sweetness, fruity tart sweetness and then moving into Smarties sweet/tart candy notes. The more I drink the more Im not getting this one. It lacks depth and interest and oddness I enjoy with some examples of this style.
Ibrew2or3.  Pours a clear golden color with a white head.  Aroma is a little bit fruit and mustiness.  Taste is sweet with some sweet fruit (ripe pear).  Slick mouth feel and smooth finish.  Not bad.
Bottle at ZBF12, Leuven, Belgium: Clear amber/golden coloured brew with fine sugar sweet taste and some sourness.

gold blond coloured body with a little white head a little sour fruity aroma a sweet candy fruity little sour taste with a sweet fruity little bitter finish

375 ml bottle. From finestshop.be.
Cloudy golden colour with tiny white head.
Moderate sourness, earth and mild fruitiness in aroma.

This one pours a small head, with a  very nice amber-copper-tangerine  colour. Smell of vinegar, apples (cider), wood. Sour and a bit funky. Not much carbonation, and maybe too light in the palate. 33cl bottle just over the date.
slightly off white head.  Clear amber pour.  Nice enough, not exciting though
Bottle 37,5 cl.... it pours clear amber with a medium creamy off white head....the aroma is sweet fruits, some dusty notes.... the flavor is very sweet, fruity, dry, loaded with berries.....
Pours clear golden with a white head. Aroma of some lambic and sugar. Flavor is sweet and fruity with some sour lambic notes.medium body, average carbonation. Too sweet.
Didnt have a lot of smell, maybe it was a little bit too cold, but i waited quite a long time and warmed it up a bit. Taste is nice.
Kind of amber colored. Smell and taste not good but the aftertaste is the worst. Musty and sourness came upon me like someone had just thrown up next to me! Im NOT drinking this beer again.
Bottle, Ship and Mitre, Liverpool. Deep gold, sour aroma with vinegar. Very sweet, mellow with a long hidden sour finish.

Bottle:
Small off white head on top of a clear darker orange colored beer.
Smell malts, sweets, wood, grains, dust, brown sugars and yeast.
Taste sweets, hint of fruits, malts, yeast, brown sugars.
Sweet brown sugary light malty aftertaste.
Low carbo, medium body, tingling mouthfeel and a light sticky texture.
user_location: Best of E-Town mit 2 Brauhausen, NETHERLANDS

text: Draft at the source.  Clear chestnut color.  Aroma of caramel, taste is all sugar.  Far too sweet for my tastebuds to handle.

Bottle.  Pours an apple juice like body with faint bubbly ring.  Aromatically vinegar, cider, apple skins, sweeter maltose and light fruit tones.  PRetty sweet with vinegar hints, light sugary notes, and a faint tartness.  Have to say im not to big a fan of this one though it seems fairly comparable to others ive had (maybe 3 total)?
Pale yellow-orange coloured beer with a small white head. Sweet aroma, Sweet and sticky taste, a bit like lemon limonade. (Bottle 33 cl)
2/21/11.  Bottle courtesy jtclockwork.  Clear golden pour with no head.  Sweet, slightly sour aroma with a very sweet flavor laced with sugar and a touch of green apple like a jolly rancher.
Bottle shared with drowland. Pours clear maple amber. Nose of sweet candi sugar and caramel. Taste of green apple jolly rancher and candi sugar.

Clear amber coloured beer with large diminishing white head and only few carbonation. A fruity sweet aroma with a little sour touch. Full bit sparkling palate. Finish is sour dry with some herby touches. (@ YC - 8/01/10)

Bottle marked as best by 10/02/11 via a trade with bu11zeye. Pours with a clear golden body and a small white head. Aromas of honey, biscuit, malic and lactic acids, apple juice, tea, sourness, baked bread. Flavors of sweet apple juice, cider, light sourness, candi sugar, and light vinegar. Not bad. Fully diminishing tall blond head. Body is clear deep gold to pale amber.  Sourish-fruity aroma, apples mostly, and maybe some dried yellow fruits.  Taste is far on the sweet side, sugar sweet that is. A light artificial fruity acidity down below. Sticky texture. Medium full. Easy drinking, but a tad too sugary for my tastebuds.
It seems to be a carmel liquor more than a beer.  It smells like a drain ditch but tastes very sweet.  It would be a great after dinner drink.  No head..good color.
20th April 2006  Warning! Early amateur rating! Slight tart and fruity. Refreshing. Not as intense as some other Faros.

Dark golden pour.  Aroma has a interesting hint of funk, hay, and lemon as well as the sweet caramel.  Flavor - not good at first sip, then it grows on you.  Medium acid, medium funkiness.  Just not my thing.

Bottle.  Pours a clear golden amber color.  Moderate off-white head with decent retention and good lacing.  Aroma is sweet citrus and some grassiness.  Flavor is an odd mix of candy sugar, lemon and some floral hops.  Medium mouthfeel and a slightly astringent finish.  Not my favorite style, but decent.

Location: 33 ml bottle at a restaurant in Brussels, 8/11/10


Aroma: The nose has lots of apple, accompanied by some other fruity notes and malty notes 

Appearance: It pours into the glass a mostly clearish orange-amber color

Flavor: The taste is slightly sour, but mostly sweet, lots of fruity notes along with some caramel

This serves as my first Fara rating, leaving me only one stlye I have yet to rate a beer from.  I can see the appeal of this stuff. Brown bottle, 33 cl, best before 24/05/09, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savoured on August 6 2010; eye: amber, clear, no effervescence, tiny ring of off-white head, no lacing; nose: farm, sugar, tomato; mouth: sugar, light farm, light vegetable, finale in sugar with presence of vegetable, light body, below-average carbonation, quite sweet, sticky texture; overall: correct

FRANÇAIS

Bouteille brune, 33 cl, meilleure avant 24/05/09, via Importations Privées Bièropholie (merci Hughes!), savourée le 6 août 2010; il : ambrée, claire, pas deffervescence, petit anneau de mousse blanc cassé, pas de dentelle; nez : ferme, sucre, tomate; bouche : sucre, léger ferme, léger légumes, finale en sucre avec présence de légume, corps léger, carbonatation sous la moyenne, pas mal sucrée, texture collante; en résumé : décevant

Best By January 2012; Sampled July 2010
Pours with a frothy, off-white head.  The beer is a darkish amber hue that shows a brilliantly clear, dark copper color when held up to the light.  The aroma smells quite sweet, then of fruit (apples, perhaps some pear, though both notes seem like oxidized versions of the fruit), there is a touch of tin, definite oxidized caramel, and something that smells sort of rich and savory smelling or perhaps a bit rotten somehow (I am not sure on this last note, but it smells of something that even Lambic shouldnt smell like).

Wow, quite sweet tasting (especially compared to Girardin Dominicus that I just had); having said that I think that it is not as sweet as Lindemans Faro. There is perhaps a touch of tartness in the finish, perhaps even a bit lemon like, but this is not very sour considering it should have a base of Lambic.  This is quite light bodied, though the sugar does give it some heft.  It is hard to really taste anything anything under the sugar; it definitely tastes like lemon-flavored sweet-tea, and there is a certain fruitiness here too.

The Lambic character seems to have made it less into this than it should have; the aroma is actually entirely devoid of anything resembling Lambic.  Not bad and sort of refreshing, b/c it is so clean, but really seems more like sweet tea with fake lemon added than anything; and I am nor really a fan of that.
Bottle. Pours gold orange with a thin fizzy head. Light sweet aroma with some lighter sour notes. The flavor is similar, sweet with a tart hint. Decent.

Bottle from Beers of Europe. Rancid sour aroma. Orange brown colour, doesnt reall look like a beer. Complex sweet mixed fruit flavour. Very interesting and it goes down well. Unusual and is growing on me.

Bottle @ home. Reddish orange, small tanned head.
Aroma of sour apple, raspberry, butter and candy sugar.
Flavour is quite sweet with a sour sidenote. 
Doesnt really blend, not my thing.

head: normal goes away after a while, white 
colour: more yellow/blond like , becomes a bit darker when aged ...
smell: sour, wheats , candy sugar , yeast, fruits 
taste: suprisingly this is a bit more sour then sweet , but nice fruitiness and even bit of hops , but im more into the balance of the " lindemans faro "
nice tough ....

Bottle 33cl. Yellow-orange color with small head. Smell is very nice with low sour and fruity notes. Taste is fine as sweet cider, with low lambic aroma which means low vinegar taste. Not bad but not very complex.

On tap at the Rake, Southwark 17/12/09.  Deep gold in colour with a white head. Tart, fruity aroma with sicoy yeast and a caramel edge. Flavour was sweet, with the sugar fairly prominent, citrus fruit, a whiff of vinegar and rounded, tart finish. Very good.
Bottle. High fluffy and long lasting off-white head. Hazy orange body. Mild vinegar hay bread fruit aroma. Sweet, mild and sugary  lemon flavor with low carbonation and a long aftertaste.
Bottle. Dark yellow body, with a small white head. Aroma and flavor is sweet and fruity.
33cl, from De Hopduvel Gent, not complex sweet brew, yet refreshing, balanced, clear, nearly no head, nothing special
Bottle. Golden colour with an off-white head. Aroma is sour, dry, yeast. Flavour is sweet, sour, candis sugar, yeast, citrus. Medium to full body. Nice beer.
Bottle. Clear golden with a thin white head. Average retention and lacing. Aroma is sweet and sour with citrus, candy and malt. Flavor is pretty much the same. Simple but refreshing.

Bottle. 
Pours an amber colour with a white head. 
It has a sweet aroma with fruits and dried apples notes to it. 
The flavour is extremely sweet with lemon and apple notes... and some extra sugar.

Bottle, 4%. Sweet and citric aroma, hint of earth. Clear light amber colour, small floating bits. The flavour is sweet with some raisin. Good citric flavour, lactic. Seems like a factory product, but tastes good.
Hazy amber body with a medium creamy off white head. Sweet fruity aroma with some light dusty notes. Very sweet falvour with some raspberry notes. Medium bodied.

bottle from Gollem in Amsterdam - Pours clear golden with a one finger head.  It smells earthy and malty.  The taste is very sweet malt and candi sugar with a little citrus and earthy flavor.  Its refreshing, but the sugar is overdone, in my opinion, though this rating is my first faro.

Pours copper with a rather dense mostly lasting white head with nice lacing. Aroma of fresh cherries and apples. Sweet apples in flavor gives this beer a refreshing cidery touch. The sweetness is well finished with a mix of sour, tartness and some bitterness. A great beer.

Bottle. A clear, almost golden beer with a finger-thick, creamy, off-white head leaving nice lacings. Slightly sugary on the nose, with citrus and some funky barnyard scents. Nicely balanced flavor with lemony sourness, white sugar and some funky notes. Sweetish, medium to full-bodied mouthfeel with some astringency. Lasting astrincent finish with some sugar to balance it. A quenching, really pleasant faro. Sure a beer for the summer. (090422)
My first Faro. Like the other Timmermans its more of an alco-pop refreshing drink. This is sweet and sour with lots of apple note in the aroma and flavour.

(Bottled) Hazy amber with a small head. Aroma of perfume, sourish-caramely malt, hints of vegetables, and honey. Heavily sugary-sweet flavor with green apple and very faint hints of the original lambic. Medium-bodied, sticky-sugary palate with low carbonation. What was once lambic, is no more... a beer completely spoiled with excess sugar.
UPDATED: AUG 18, 2009 Bottle at Lautre Oeil. Hazy amber with small white head. Aroma is apple, sour and funky. Taste is sour and fruity. Body is onctuous. Great beer ! Rating #57
Golden body with medium head. Sour and malty nose. Very sweet, with fruit and caramel tastes. Quite tart - not as much as I feared. Okay.

Clear golden with a medium white head. Aroma was sweet with sourish and malty notes.flavour was sweet witj fruity and malty notes. Flavour was sweet with plenty of fruity and caramel notes. Flavour was sweet wiith caranel anand vinius notes.
had this with Oldrtybastrd.  This was my first taste of a lambic.  For what it is it was not bad.  It poured amber with a lot of sour apple aroma and taste.  One of these is enough.

Bottle 33cl. @ home.Clear medium amber orange color with a average to large, frothy, good lacing, mostly lasting, white to off-white head. Aroma is apple prune acidic - sour, brown sugar. Flavor is moderate to light heavy sweet with a average duration, and a dry finish. Body is medium, texture is oily, carbonation is soft. (220808)

Courtesy of SkyCop32.  Picked up at Maruhn Getränke in Darmstadt.  5 pack w/ glass and coasters.  Pours a brown reddish color.  Aromas of friut(sour apple) musty.  Flavor is a subdued tart  taste, not a big as I expected.  Medium bodied with a slight tart mouthfeel.  This is a great beer.

Bottle pours dark amber with a thin white head.  Has a sweet, tart, and fruity aroma.  Mouthfeel is medium with a slight carbonation to it.  Flavor is sweet, tart, and overall a descent brew.  Not quite as sweet as the last faro I had.  This one was more tart.  But unfortunately this one didn’t have as much flavor either.

Deep reddy brown with small diminishing head that leaves a nice lacing. Sweet, fruity aroma. Sticky consistency, starts with light fruity (cherries, grapes) with accompanying dryness and ends with cranberries and vanilla and cured ham (!). Very sweet but becomes drinkable after a bit.

Bottle, bought @ Skjold Burne, Aarhus.
Pours a deep, coppery golden with a large, bubbly, off-white head. Aroma is lightly tart, some apples, grapes and white wine. High and lively carbonation, fine mouthfeel. Flavour is quite sweet, an underlying fruity tartness. Refreshing and very nice. Some slight sweet caramel creep in at the end.
Bottle, Gollem, Amsterdam. A very sweet and uncomplicated faro that reminds me of asti and apple juice. Very refreshing!

Bottle.  Sour milk, toffee, and sugar aroma.  Hazy brown color with small head.  Intense sweetness and slightly sour musty malt flavor.  Seemed cloying at first but then more drinkable as I drank more. One of the sweeter faros.

Well here it is:  my first Faro rating.  Its funny, because Ive tried many Faros before I started rating, and the first one I rate isnt exactly the best of the bunch.  Bought at Takanaya, shared with my Japanese wife and mother in law.  Nice lactic sour aroma.  Im  looking forward to tasting it....wait, I was looking forward to it.  Now that Ive tasted it, it is oddly sweet and very little sour, as if something bad is being covered up.  I love sour, and I love sweet, but this is a little too much.  Caramel and some grapefruit.  Syrupy texture.  Its just the low drinkability that gets an otherwise good beer.

Bottle (in NZ), pouring a cloudy dark amber, no head. A sweet gingery malt aroma, I dont detect much sourness. A pleasantly sour palate, with a strong but not too sweet candy sugar flavour. I wouldnt drink a lot of it (the finish is just too sweet), but I actually rate this beer reasonably well.

Warm golden with a lot of tiny bubbles rising in the glass. The aroma has slightly sour and malty, smooth. The flavour has the same notes, the caramel is very smooth, and I also get notes of fruit. Its both sour and sweet  quite charming.

12oz bottle thanks to Boutip. My first Faro. Poured golden in color with a champagne like large fizzy head that was quickly diminishing. Aroma was of sweet candi sugar with a bit of tartness. Taste was of granny smith apple tartness, pixy stick sugar, slight funky yeast taste.  Surprised this isnt rated any better for what it is.
Botella 330 Ml. Aroma y sabor frutal. manzana quizás. se puede tomar perfectamente.

Bottle: Poured a deep orangey color lambic with a small foamy head with not much retention or lacing. Aroma of sour and tart notes with some light funk is surprising  nothing close to actual lambic but still retains some of the characteristics. Taste is quite sweet with some tart notes with some light oak. Not sure why apple juice was added in there but it was not overly noticeable.

UPDATED: JAN 17, 2010 300ml bottle (Delirium, Brussels)
Clear deep amber, thin head. Slightly sharp but candiflossy aroma. Apple and similar sharp fruity tastes, but overpowered by sickly sugary sweetness. (5-3-5-3-9=2.5)
Rerate: Keg (Rake, London) - shared by MagicDave - chinchin!
Sharp fruity citrus aroma. Crisp and refreshing. Good for a modern sweet one. Even stuffed from a curry buffet, I could happily sip at this. (6-4-7-4-13=3.4)
Amber colour, white head. Aroma is sour and musty, horseblanket. Flavour is sour, of apple and candy sugar. Smooth. Drinkable.
Unusal aroma, hard to describe, sory (New word) Sour sweet flavour. Gold in colour with small white head, refreshing mouthfeel.

33cl bottle, via jbrus.  Pours a mostly clear dark gold to light amber body under a fizzy thin off-white head that sounded like a soda.  The head retreated quickly to a thin ring and a small island.   The nose is mostly simple sugar syrup, but there is a slight underlying Gueuze-like cellar mustiness.  Theres definately some acidity there in the flavor, but the sugar pretty well blankets it from the middle to the finish.  A little cellar funkiness hides in the finish.  Mouthfeel is extremely fizzy, almost champagne like.  The high sugar content actually makes for a pretty full bodied and heavy thickness.  A little clingyness on the finish.  Overall, this was actually pretty decent.  Out of the now six bottled Faros that Ive had this was just one tick away from being tied for the best with the Girardin.

Bottled.
Cresmy and adherent head of discreet duration. Beautiful dark orange color with reddish glares and good fizz. Hazy and elegant aspect. Acidulous aroma with sugary and sweetish notes, withered grape and new wine. Much lively taste, sweet, sour, fizzy and with notes of candy, sugar cane and yeast.

Dark amber coloured with very little carbonation and a very small white head. Smouth sweeter malty fruity woody aroma. Medium palate, with a lot of sprankling. Finish is light bitter sour, fruity, nice balanced. Good One.

Pours amber with a thin white head.  This one actually had more carbonation than the others.  Smells of sugar, some rotten fruit, horseblankets (to use a cliche), some barnyard funk.  Taste yields some nice sourness balanced out by the sugar added.  The best of the faros I sampled.

Clear apple/caramel type amber body. Thin white head, slow recession, never fully. The nose imparts notes of yeasty apple cider, mold, mild lambic funk, stale sugarcane, Muenster cheese and vines. The flavor doles out light farmhouse funk and lacto notes, heavy candi sugar and remains stale. Light bodied, syrupy sweet - not cloying but almost tooth-rottingly sugary. Finishes with apple and yeast notes, sweet. Id be happy never sampling this again. I love lambic, as long as it isnt Faro. This is one of the least respectable offerings of the style Ive encountered.

Bottle at In De Wildeman, Amsterdam. Grilled cheese, light tart aroma. Taste has good tart under the sugar, and is rich and well balanced. Very drinkable and well done. Definitely one of the better bottle faros.

Bottle. Sweet, a little bit of cherry. Small fizzy white head, fully diminishing. Red clear body. Moderate sweet start, moderate acetic finish (nice one). Average duration. Light body, very dry texture, lively carbonation, heavy astringent finish.
Very nice refreshing drink.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear amber body with a small white head.  Aroma of apple, mint leaves, and lemon.  Flavor of syrupy sourness (peach, apple) with a sticky finish.

Bottle. Body-dark iced tea with a thin ring of bubble. Nose-apple and cinnamon, Russian tea, apple juice. Taste-very low funk, very low horse, artificial sweetener, medium tart tastes like artificially sweetened apple juice. Much better than the last Frao that I had.

Clearish amber pour wearing a small white cover. Rather bland nose of sugary candies and green apple. A certain acidity grows in, mostly fruity, but the ending result is a dull and sweet brew that serves no purpose at all. Well carbonated body fortunately and that cuts a bit through the sweetness.

Ah, a nice beer at last from Timmermans. Its nothing mindblowing, but its just so easy to drink. A beautiful refreshing sourness without being too palate-destroying. Id like to have this on draught and enjoy it all night. The relatively high rating reflects an enjoyable experience rather than a great beer.
Bottle. Little hazy light amber colour with a little head. Sour and sweet aroma with hints of fruit. Also flavour of sweet, fruity and little sourness. Ends up sweet and very refreshing.
Bottled. Amber colour, small white head. Aroma is slightly sweet and a bit sour. Candy sugar meets sourness. Flavour mainly the same with some appleish hints. Very dry, not that sour in flavour.

Bottle.  [Thanks to yespr for sharing this one]   Average rocky off-white head that mostly diminished. Clear flat looking body with a golden color. Aroma of vinegar, earth, dusty grain, caramel and citrus. It defiantly had a light Lambic aroma going. Medium bodied with an average carbonation and light sticky texture. Light sweet with moderated acidic notes. Ok Faro.
Bottle.  Golden brown beer with a strong head.  The aroma is fruity and slightly yeasty, and the flavour is nicely sweet, refreshing and fruity.  Overall a nice beer.

Bottle from Papsoe! Nose of lightly tart horseblanket; very slightly hazed goldish copper with a medium but quick disapating straw colored head; flavor is slightly sweet apples, with a tart funkiness, the least sweet of the five faros Ive tasted. Nice tart appley finish. Very similiar to the Girardin faro.
From 33 cL bottle. Pours slight hazy orange with little head. Sweet sour lambic aroma. Apple sour and slight sweet flavour. Dry sour finish. Nice.

the guy taht sold this to me hyped it up but im not impressed... aroma is almost nonexistant soursweet, appearance is mediocre at best... taste and palate are better, very fruity, almost cidery but i wont be shitting my pants over this one anytime

Ochre color with a thin white head that lasts a moment. Very carbonated. Smells of apple and cane sugar. Taste of malts, cane sugar and apple is very sweet and delicate. Acetic and a bit yeasty. Quiet enjoyable. Creamy palate and good sweet spicy and sour finish. (It is a kind of mix between cava and natural cider)
Bottle. Golden colour with a medium mostly lasting head. Aroma and taste of malts and cane sugar. Well balanced. Very good faro.
Creamy white good mostly lasting head. Dark yellow colour. Heavy malty aroma. Light yeasty. Light sweet flavor. Very acetic but well-balanced. Long complex finish. Creamy palate. Good stuff.
Bottle. Medium head with medium duration. Color is golden-amber and a bit hazy. Aroma is citric and a bit sour. Taste is a nice balance between lactose acid and sugar.

Pours a hazy brown beer with a small white head. Subdued aromas of lemon and some candy sugar. Sweet taste with citric acidity, some candy sugar and green apples. Tart, fruity finish. Bit watery palate. Not bad, but ive had better faros.

33cl bottle from Noel Cuveliers, Abele.  Amber clear colour with lasting thin white head.  Some acidic lambic aroma, rather muted like cider.  Relatively sweet in mouth.  Finish has growing sweetness, bit of carbonation tingle in mouth.  Rather sweet to be honest.  Aroma is not bad, bit of lemon on finish too.  Just a bit too sweet.
Sourish but balanced is how this has been discribed.  Orange.  Sour, sweet aroma.  A bit or citrus ... orange?  Lemon? In the end ... just over sweet.
Bottle. Orange colour. Sour, fruity and sweet aroma. Fresh sour fruity apple flavour, some lemon. Tasty indeed!

A Mes rate: Bottle from a bar in Manchester that I can not remember the name of. Faros are rarely good, this is no exception. Slight sourness and some general sweetness. Overall it is acidic and not too great. One dimensional.

Cloudy copper body topped by a white ring.  As with most faro the dominant flavours are sweetness with some sourness.  Like a candy coated apple.  More than just sweet, this is sugary sweet.  The fruity flavours were all over the place with apple, cherries, raspberries, pineapples, strawberries and watermelon.  The finish has a champagne-ish acidity but lacked the dryness of a real gueuze/lambic.  There was a little butterscotch flavour there too that just seemed wrong and out of place.  For some this can be fun in small quantity but I find it quickly gets gross.  Since I drank this Faro Tradition I have a faro related tradition of my own, every day of the week I make sure that I dont drink another Faro Tradition.

[Bottled]
Amber. No almost no head. Yeast sediments.
Sweet, sugary nose.
Both sweet and sour in the flavour.
Orange/amber, with lots of yeast in the bottle. Small white head. Sour and fruity aroma, woody, some oak and with rubber notes. Quite sweet flavor, fruity and with oaky notes.

On draught at Brasserie Ploegmans, Brussels. Peachy golden with a small head. Sweet fruity nose with some citrus. Very sweet and fruity, hints of citrus and some wood. Wel-carbonated, light body. A good thirst-quencher on a warm day.

Many thanks to Immy for this rare find!  From bottle, pours a hazy orange yellow with white head.  Nose is light overall and resembles rice pudding, with a light tartness underneath.  Flavor is sweet cookie and lightly tart.  Enjoyed this one, but it didnt stretch any boundaries.

From my Danish Secret Santa - thanks, whoever you are! Slightly hazy gold, nice white head. Medium tart nose, apples, some honeylike notes, mildly musty. Sweet flavor, sugary, apples and wood. Funky, sweet, mildly tart finish.

Mild aroma of apples and herbal, leafy woodiness.  Hazy burnished copper coloured body is topped by a low off white head that recedes to partial cover and ring.  Fairly sweet up front with some tea-like tannins and a waxy note in the finish.  Overcarbonated and somewhat watery in texture.  Tulip glass.  Cellar temperature.  Bottle (Bièropholie, Mar-06).

This was a winner and my favorite lambic to-date. Hooray to faros (if only they were more commonplace here in the states). Pour wasnt exciting, nice little head from the carbonation and average lacing, but the color was boring (cloudy amber yellow or so, looking into the plastic cup). The aroma was funky (barn-like), citric, and somewhat apple-like. The flavor was outstanding, a nice blend of sweetness and tart sourness. Came across with the balance of a good Flemish Sour, but with the lighter flavors more strong (no vinegar) and a wheat-like base prominent. Sour apples (cidery) were detected. The mouthfeel was light and carbonated, somewhat soda-like.

Rather odd take on the traditional Lambic and not exactly what I expected of a Faro. Tasted from the stylish new labelled bottle with a vintage black & white photo of the brewhouse. Into a lambic flute, a bright ruddy gold with small speckles of yeast floating about. Head formed to a creamy consistency and held for the length producing excellent lacing. Generous aroma I could easily pick up from across the room; reminiscent of mushrooms, sweet caramel, vanilla yoghurt and some barnyard musty and equally tart wheat. Later on it showed a little spicy and fresh fruit like apples, pears and lemons. Wow, first sip almost rattled my teeth loose as it was like chopped lemon and white sugar. Sweetness quickly subsides to reveal some tart and sour citrus fruit, musty goat-hair and light oaky notes that dry it out and a little white wine thats beyond its shy ABV. Body is very light with just a tickle of carbonation upfront before crossing the tongue with a creamy, smooth roundness. Finish seems short, fresh and fruity yet a musty vapour like dank hessian cloth lingers in the back of the mouth (actually a good thing). Not complex like the greater Lambics and the style is one that is barely surviving modern times, yet personally I liked it. Fresh, fruity and summery. Not bad!!! (33cL, BB 09/02/07, Intl Beer Shop, W. Leederville)
Couleur blond doré. Mousse peu abondante. Grosses bulles. Pétille sur la langue en attaque, acidité présente en finale. Goût de pomme verte. Odeur indescriptible, vinaigre (?).

Sweetened lemonade, light wood, tart fruits, and light vinegar. Body is light and bubbly. Finishes too sweet. Light fruit and wood but some artificial sweetener-like flavors to this.

Dark golden faro with a thick collapsing white head. Pleasant aroma of green apples, light barnyard, and acid points. In mouth, acidic and sweet, with definite tart apples and some cherries, a bit earthy, but very tame. Bottle from Bieropholie.

The pour reveals a clear amber color with a medium diminishing offwhite head. Aroma of tart green apples with some acidity and sweet cookies. The flavor is classis for a lambic, tart green apples with acidity and some mustyness but its weak, the sweet cookies are also felt in the flavor, the finish is astringent and sweet. The body is light with a dry texture and medium carbonation. Not bad but too weak to be considered authentic.
Looks like clear apple juice. Sweet and sour flavors with aromas of grapes and apples. Fizzy carbonation. Very metallic sour finish. Nice refreshing Lambic... but I guess I like the weaker lambics.

Mid amber with a large white head. The aroma was sour and vinegary at first. Later the warmth brought out the sugar. The taste had a restrained apple and lemon sourness balanced by sweetness. My first faro, and I enjoyed it.

Robe cuivrée aux reflets rosés très claire surmontée dune mousse blanche épaisse en dentelle qui sestompe. Arômes acides, de chêne et de sucre. Saveurs de pommes, de fraises, de canneberges, de cassonade et de houblon.

Yellow honey golden color, with a white head, but is falling quickly. The nose has a sweet malty, tartness, oakiness notes, with a hint of wineyness, and a wet wood aroma, follows through on a medium-bodied palate, with a sweet sourness apples flavor, a nice sweet oakiness and tartness accents, with a malt sweetness, the lambic sweet and sour character is evident. The sweet side from the candy sugar added in this lambic, gives the beer his quenching aspect, its why this lambic version is called faro, leading towards a well refreshing sourness and a mild sweet and tart acidic pleasant finish. I love this beer, even if it has a more commercial approach and easy to drink spontaneous fermented lambic, than to the more traditional lambic.
